## Customer Support Integrations with Asana

Asana offers several integrations specifically designed for customer support teams:

### Popular Customer Support Integrations:

1. **HappyFox Help Desk Integration**
   - By integrating Asana with HappyFox, you can manage your create new tasks, track task progress, keep different teams in sync, and ultimately, deliver superior customer service.
   - Sync Asana task comments and HappyFox ticket updates. All changes in either of the products are synced with the other.

2. **SupportBee Integration**
   - Create a task in Asana with just one click from the customer email in SupportBee.
   - With this SupportBee integration, support agents can create Asana tasks for the development team directly.

3. **Userback**
   - Userback lets you snap, annotate and receive customer feedback as a new task in your Asana projects.

### General Integration Capabilities:
Connect your customer support team to your product, engineering, and sales teams and share valuable customer feedback with your entire company.

You can explore more integrations on Asana's official apps page at asana.com/apps, where they offer connections with various tools to enhance customer support workflows.

I found the official Asana API documentation for you. Here are the main resources:

## Official Asana API Documentation

**Main Documentation Site:** developers.asana.com

**Key Resources:**

1. **REST API Reference** (https://developers.asana.com/reference/rest-api-reference) - The Asana API is a RESTful interface with predictable resource-oriented URLs, accepts JSON or form-encoded requests, returns JSON, and uses standard HTTP features

2. **Quick Start Guide** (https://developers.asana.com/docs/quick-start) - Build your first app with a step by step quick start guide that teaches you to create and authorize with a token then create tasks via the API

3. **API Explorer** (https://developers.asana.com/docs/api-explorer) - Asana's REST API reference allows you to explore different REST API endpoints through an in-context, easy-to-use interface where you can make API requests and view responses directly in your browser

4. **API Features Guide** (https://developers.asana.com/docs/api-features) - Provides programmatic access to much of the data in the system with predictable URLs for accessing resources

The documentation includes comprehensive guides, API endpoints for tasks, projects, and other resources, along with an interactive API explorer for testing requests.

I've found information about Asana API integration for 2025. Here's what's available:

## Official Asana API Resources

Asana's API allows you to build apps that automate repeatable processes, like creating follow-up tasks, sending updates, or organizing projects. The Asana API is a RESTful interface with predictable resource-oriented URLs, accepts JSON or form-encoded requests, returns JSON, and uses standard HTTP features.

## Getting Started

Most developers test the API by creating a Personal Access Token (PAT) to make their first API calls. You can create your token or app in the developer console.

## Integration Capabilities

The Asana API enables several key benefits:

- Automate manual tasks and workflows within Asana, saving your team significant time and effort
- Integrate Asana with other business applications you use daily, eliminating the need to switch between different platforms
- Access to raw project data, allowing you to generate custom reports and gain deeper insights into project performance

## Available Integrations

Asana connects with tools like Slack, Dropbox, Instagantt, and Google Drive, and Asana's APIs let you develop custom solutions for your team and the way you work.

For detailed documentation, you can visit the official Asana Developers site and their REST API Reference.

I found several examples of Asana bug tracking integrations. Here are the key integration options:

## Popular Asana Bug Tracking Integrations

### **Marker.io**
Marker.io is a website feedback and annotation tool that helps report bugs and collect website feedback into Asana.(no content)The integration automatically captures technical metadata, screenshots, and technical logs that get attached to Asana tasks, and allows reporting issues directly from staging or UAT environments.

### **Usersnap**
Usersnap integrated with Asana to provide visual bug tracking capabilities. Each annotation added in Usersnap is automatically added as a project task in Asana.(no content)Usersnap is a visual bug tracking solution that identifies, captures, and resolves issues with screen recordings, screenshots, and contextual feedback.

### **ShakeBug**
ShakeBug allows users to either sync existing Asana tasks to ShakeBug or create new bugs in ShakeBug and have them automatically added to Asana tasks.(no content)The integration automates bug-tracking tasks, saving time and reducing errors, with customizable bug reports that provide all the information needed to fix issues efficiently.

### **Instabug**
Instabug integration provides annotated screenshots and device details with bug reports in Asana.(no content)Bugs and users' feedback can be converted to Asana tasks with just a click.

### **Capture.dev**
Capture.dev creates Asana tasks directly from your website with all the context automatically captured, generating a complete Asana task with all the info your team needs.

### **Feedbucket**
Feedbucket automatically syncs feedback information to Asana, and when a task is marked as Completed in Asana, the client receives an email notification that the bug has been fixed.

These integrations generally provide automated bug capture with screenshots, technical metadata, and device details, streamlining the bug reporting process and reducing manual data entry into Asana.

I found comprehensive information about implementing Asana webhooks. Here's what you need to know:

## Setting Up Asana Webhooks

To work with Asana webhooks, you must create and host a server that can receive and handle webhook events, and this server must expose an HTTP endpoint (a publicly-accessible URL) to function as the reception and processing point for all incoming events.

## Implementation Process

Establishing a webhook is a two-part process: First, a simple HTTP POST request initiates the creation similar to creating any other resource, and next, in the middle of this request comes the confirmation handshake.

### The Handshake
When a webhook is created, Asana will send a test POST to the target with an X-Hook-Secret header, and the target must respond with a 200 OK or 204 No Content and a matching X-Hook-Secret header to confirm that this webhook subscription is indeed expected.(no content)It's strongly recommended to store this secret to be used to verify future webhook event signatures.

## Key Technical Details

**Event Delivery**: Webhooks and events streams are served from the same infrastructure, where, on average, events are delivered within a minute of occurring, and most should be delivered within 10 minutes of occurring.

**Reliability**: This system is designed for at-most-once delivery, meaning in exceptional circumstances Asana may fail to deliver events, and furthermore, webhooks cannot be replayed once delivered.

**Timeout**: If your server does not respond to a webhook with a successful HTTP status code within 10 seconds, Asana will try to resend the webhook for up to 24 hours before giving up.

## Development Resources

For implementation examples, see Asana's sample webhook server implementation in Node.js and Python.(no content)During development and testing, if you set up a server on your local machine (a localhost service), you may choose to use a "tunneling" tool such as ngrok to expose that local server to the internet.

The official Asana webhooks documentation at developers.asana.com provides detailed guides and API references for implementing webhooks in 2025.

Asana App Development Overview:

Key Characteristics:
- Extends Asana's functionality
- Can integrate with other tools
- Automate workflows
- Add or extract Work Graph data

App Types:
1. Shareable apps (published in App Directory)
2. Organization-specific apps

Getting Started Steps:
1. Understand Work Graph and object hierarchy
2. Plan app's specific purpose
3. Choose authentication method
4. Test API calls

Authentication Options:
- Personal Access Token (PAT)
- OAuth (recommended)
- Service Account token

API Features:
- REST API
- Webhooks
- App Components
- Batch requests
- Custom fields support

Development Best Practices:
- Use API explorer for testing
- Familiarize with object relationships
- Choose appropriate hosting solution
- Consider distribution settings

Recommended Development Resources:
- API Reference documentation
- Developer Console
- Example apps on GitHub
- Client libraries (JavaScript, Python, Ruby, Java, PHP)

Deployment Considerations:
- Local script deployment
- Cloud hosting options (AWS, Google Cloud, Heroku)
- Security and uptime requirements

The documentation emphasizes thorough planning, understanding Asana's platform, and iterative development as key to successful app creation.

Here's a concise summary of the Asana API Quick Start Guide:

Quick Start Guide for Asana API
-------------------------------

### Prerequisites
- Experience with REST principles
- Basic understanding of HTTP and JSON
- cURL installed (pre-installed on MacOS/Linux, downloadable for Windows)

### Setup Steps
1. Get a Personal Access Token (PAT)
   - Go to Asana Developer Console
   - Click "Create new token"
   - Name the token
   - Copy and securely store the token

2. Find Your Workspace GID
   - Log into Asana
   - Visit: `https://app.asana.com/api/1.0/workspaces`
   - Note the `gid` for your workspace

### Basic API Operations (Task Example)

1. Create a Task
   - Endpoint: `POST /tasks`
   - Example Request:
     ```
     curl --request POST \
       --url 'https://app.asana.com/api/1.0/tasks' \
       --header 'authorization: Bearer ACCESS_TOKEN' \
       --data '{ "data": { "workspace": "WORKSPACE_GID", "name": "Sample task", "assignee": "me" } }'
     ```

2. Get a Task
   - Endpoint: `GET /tasks/{task_gid}`
   - Example Request:
     ```
     curl --request GET \
       --url https://app.asana.com/api/1.0/tasks/TASK_GID \
       --header 'authorization: Bearer ACCESS_TOKEN'
     ```

3. Update a Task
   - Endpoint: `PUT /tasks/{task_gid}`
   - Example Request:
     ```
     curl --request PUT \
       --url 'https://app.asana.com/api/1.0/tasks/TASK_GID' \
       --header 'authorization: Bearer ACCESS_TOKEN' \
       --data '{ "data": { "name": "Modified task" } }'
     ```

4. Delete a Task
   - Endpoint: `DELETE /tasks/{task_gid}`
   - Example Request:
     ```
     curl --request

   - Go to Asana Developer Console
   - Click "Create new token"
   - Name the token
   - Copy and securely store the token

2. Find Your Workspace GID
   - Log into Asana
   - Visit: `https://app.asana.com/api/1.0/workspaces`
   - Note the `gid` for your workspace

### Basic API Operations (Task Example)

1. Create a Task
   - Endpoint: `POST /tasks`
   - Example Request:
     ```
     curl --request POST \
       --url 'https://app.asana.com/api/1.0/tasks' \
       --header 'authorization: Bearer ACCESS_TOKEN' \
       --data '{ "data": { "workspace": "WORKSPACE_GID", "name": "Sample task", "assignee": "me" } }'
     ```

2. Get a Task
   - Endpoint: `GET /tasks/{task_gid}`
   - Example Request:
     ```
     curl --request GET \
       --url https://app.asana.com/api/1.0/tasks/TASK_GID \
       --header 'authorization: Bearer ACCESS_TOKEN'
     ```

3. Update a Task
   - Endpoint: `PUT /tasks/{task_gid}`
   - Example Request:
     ```
     curl --request PUT \


Here's a comprehensive overview of Asana's Webhook Implementation Guide:

Webhook Overview
----------------
Webhooks allow applications to receive real-time notifications of changes in Asana, "pushing" events via HTTP POST instead of polling.

Key Implementation Steps:
1. Create a publicly accessible server endpoint
2. Complete webhook handshake
3. Implement event verification
4. Process incoming webhook events

Handshake Mechanism
-------------------
The webhook handshake involves:
- Establishing a webhook connection
- Receiving a secret from Asana
- Echoing back the secret
- Verifying the connection

Event Characteristics
---------------------
- Delivered within 1 minute on average
- Most events arrive within 10 minutes
- Events are "compact" and require additional API calls for full details
- Support multiple event types: added, changed, deleted, removed, undeleted

Security Considerations
----------------------
- Verify each webhook using HMAC signature
- Compare `X-Hook-Signature` with computed signature
- Use `X-Hook-Secret` for signature generation

Filtering Options
-----------------
- Filter events by resource type and action
- Specify granular event triggers
- Reduce unnecessary event volume

Limits and Constraints
---------------------
- 1,000 webhooks per resource
- 10,000 webhooks per authorization token
- Automatic deletion after 24 hours of failed delivery

Best Practices
--------------
- Implement robust error handling
- Respond to heartbeat events
- Handle potential event duplications
- Monitor webhook delivery status

Recommended Implementation Languages
------------------------------------
- Node.js
- Python
- Supports multiple client libraries

Troubleshooting
---------------
- Check signature computation
- Monitor delivery status indicators
- Handle heartbeat events
- Manage webhook connection lifecycle

The guide provides comprehensive documentation for developers to effectively implement and manage Asana webhooks.

Based on the documentation, here's a comprehensive overview of the Tasks API endpoint:

Tasks Overview:
- Tasks are the fundamental object in Asana, representing work items
- Can be created, updated, deleted, and organized within projects and workspaces

Key Task Properties:
- `gid`: Unique identifier
- `name`: Task title
- `notes`: Task description
- `assignee`: User responsible for the task
- `due_on/due_at`: Deadline dates
- `completed`: Boolean status
- `custom_fields`: Customizable metadata
- `projects`: Associated project(s)
- `tags`: Categorization labels
- `followers`: Users tracking the task

Task Creation Endpoint:
- HTTP Method: POST
- Requires workspace specification
- Can add to multiple projects simultaneously
- Supports setting custom fields, assignees, due dates

Task Update Endpoint:
- HTTP Method: PUT
- Can modify most task properties
- Supports partial updates

Advanced Task Management:
- Add/remove projects
- Create subtasks
- Manage dependencies
- Add attachments
- Add/remove tags
- Track time

Notable Features:
- Supports task templates
- Allows setting task status (e.g., milestone, approval)
- Provides detailed metadata tracking

The documentation provides comprehensive details for developers integrating Asana's task management capabilities.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Asana API rate limits and best practices:

## Rate Limit Structure

Asana enforces multiple kinds of rate limiting to protect API stability. Requests that hit rate limits receive a 429 Too Many Requests response with a Retry-After header. Limits are allocated per authorization token, with different tokens having independent limits.

## Types of Rate Limits

1. **Standard Rate Limits**: Based on minute-long windows, differing between free and paid domains

2. **Cost-Based Limits**: Additional limits based on computational cost protect against requests requiring extensive graph traversal. The cost limit quota is set high enough that it only affects users making requests that would compromise API stability.

## Best Practices

1. **Use Client Libraries**: Client libraries automatically respect rate-limited responses and wait appropriately before retrying

2. **Optimize Requests**: Fetching minimal fields (name and gid) requires fewer resources than fetching all task attributes

3. **Handle 429 Responses**: Implement proper retry logic that respects the Retry-After header when receiving 429 errors

4. **Token Management**: Since limits are per token, consider using multiple authorization tokens for different purposes or bot users to distribute load across independent rate limit quotas

The documentation shows that developers should focus on minimizing the computational cost of requests by only fetching necessary fields and properly handling rate limit responses.

I found search results related to Asana custom fields API issues. Here's what I found:

## Common API Issues with Custom Fields

The search results reveal several recurring bugs and challenges developers face when working with Asana's custom fields API:

### Key Issues Found:

1. **"Value cannot be an array" Error**: The API isn't symmetrical so developers can't FETCH and PUT a task (the JSON exactly as it's FETCHed) without a "Value cannot be an array error" as custom fields are not expected to be an array when posted. This bug has occurred "all of sudden" and breaks integrations with Asana used to create tasks.

2. **Number Field Format Bug**: When creating a custom field via the API, the format field is ignored and leaves number custom fields as unformatted, and updating the custom field format via PUT request also ignores the format field.

3. **Updating Custom Field Values**: Multiple developers report difficulty updating custom field values, with developers unable to update a custom field on a task and errors stating "Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'hasOwnProperty')".

4. **Project Custom Fields Error**: Developers trying to mass update fields on projects report that pushing values doesn't work at all.

### Bug Severity Context:

Teams use various fields for showing task priority including severity, priority, bug severity, and need severity, indicating that severity is a common custom field type used for bug tracking workflows in Asana.

These issues span from 2018 to 2024, suggesting some are ongoing or recurring problems with the API.

## Official Asana Client Libraries on GitHub

Asana has 189 repositories available on GitHub, including official client libraries for multiple programming languages:

### Python
The official Python client library for the Asana API v1 is available at `Asana/python-asana`. It includes examples for:
- Getting users with asana-enable headers for string IDs
- Making async requests for task creation
- Getting tasks with project filtering using access tokens

### Node.js/JavaScript
The official node.js and browser JS client for the Asana API v1 is at `Asana/node-asana`. Examples include:
- PUT requests to update tasks with authentication tokens
- DELETE operations for task management

### Other Languages
- **PHP**: The Asana PHP SDK is no longer supported and will not receive bug fixes or enhancements
- **Java**: Available at `Asana/java-asana` with OAuth 2 support and handling of OAuth flow details

## Example Code Resources

The devrel-examples repository on GitHub contains more example code, sorted by programming language. This repository includes examples from the Developer Relations team for commonly-asked-about workflows.

The examples section contains use cases, scripts, and applications using Asana's API, including how to make first API requests using popular client libraries.

## Additional Resources

The Asana/openapi repository contains the OpenAPI Specification for Asana's APIs, which can help with understanding the API structure and generating code examples.

Based on the search results, here are the key use cases for Asana API creative automation:

## Creative Workflow Automation Use Cases

### 1. **Creative Request Management**
Creative workflows can be automated using Rules to assign, notify, and hand off work automatically as projects progress, with custom rules to instantly assign, update, and schedule work for new requests.

### 2. **Smart Task Naming for Creative Projects**
AI-powered rules can rename tasks when forms are submitted using key form fields (like campaign name + due date), which is needed to avoid "Untitled creative request" cluttering your project.

### 3. **Creative Review and Approval Workflows**
Creative reviews can be managed within Asana by using Adobe Creative Cloud and Figma integrations for attaching files and receiving feedback.(no content)Integrations like GoVisually sync with Asana tasks to easily track creative proofs, feedback, revisions, and approvals for creative work.

### 4. **Automated Creative Production Processes**
AI Studio can power use cases including campaign management, creative production, as well as project and request tracking.

### 5. **Task Assignment and Triage**
A common use case is building triage bots that assign tasks, particularly among users who work with support inboxes or request projects.

### 6. **Form Validation and Quality Control**
Rules can check new tasks for missing or vague information and automatically post clarifying comments, saving project managers from chasing people down.

### 7. **Cross-Tool Integration**
One of the most common use cases for Asana's API is to integrate two different commonly used tools for getting work done.(no content)You might build custom integrations, connect Asana with internal apps or tools, or set up custom automations.

content.content:
Here's a comprehensive summary of Asana's API rate limits:

Rate Limit Types:
1. Standard Rate Limits (per minute)
- Free Domain: 150 requests
- Paid Domain: 1,500 requests

2. Concurrent Request Limits
- GET Requests: Maximum 50 concurrent
- Write Requests (POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE): Maximum 15 concurrent

3. Cost-Based Limits
- Dynamic computational cost quota
- Limits based on graph traversal complexity
- Prevents resource-intensive API calls

Special Endpoint Limits:
- Search API: 60 requests per minute
- Duplication/Export Endpoints: 5 concurrent jobs per user

Response Handling:
- 429 "Too Many Requests" error when limits exceeded
- Includes `Retry-After` header with wait time
- Client libraries automatically handle retries

Best Practices:
- Avoid deeply nested subtasks
- Limit projects with large task volumes
- Remove unused webhooks
- Use client libraries that respect rate limits

Key Recommendation: Monitor request complexity and frequency to prevent hitting rate limits.

- Write Requests (POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE): Maximum 15 concurrent

3. Cost-Based Limits
- Dynamic computational cost quota
- Limits based on graph traversal complexity
- Prevents resource-intensive API calls

Special Endpoint Limits:
- Search API: 60 requests per minute
- Duplication/Export Endpoints: 5 concurrent jobs per user

Response Handling:
- 429 "Too Many Requests" error when limits exceeded
- Includes `Retry-After` header with wait time
- Client libraries automatically handle retries

Best Practices:
- Avoid deeply nested subtasks
- Limit projects with large task volumes
- Remove unused webhooks
- Use client libraries that respect rate limits

Key Recommendation: Monitor request complexity and frequency to prevent hitting rate limits.

content.content:
Here's a comprehensive guide to custom fields in Asana based on the documentation:

Custom Fields Overview
---------------------
Custom fields allow users to add extra information to tasks, projects, and portfolios beyond built-in Asana fields.

Types of Custom Fields
---------------------
1. Text: Short string of text (max 1024 characters)
2. Number: Numeric value with precision
3. Enum: Single selection from predefined options
4. Multi-enum: Multiple selections from options
5. Date: Reference date with optional time
6. People: List of active contributors

Key Characteristics
------------------
- Can be workspace-wide or project/portfolio-specific
- Metadata defines field properties
- Tasks can have custom field values assigned
- Each field includes a read-only `display_value`

Example Use Case: Bug Tracking
------------------------------
Create a "Priority" enum custom field with options:
- Low
- Medium 
- High

Creating a Custom Field
----------------------
Two methods:
1. Workspace-wide: Use `Create a custom field` endpoint
2. Project-specific: Use `Add custom field to project` endpoint

Code Example for Creating Enum Field
------------------------------------
```json
{
    "data": {
        "custom_field": {
            "name": "Priority",
            "enum_options": [
                {"name": "Low"},
                {"name": "Medium"},
                {"name": "High"}
            ],
            "resource_subtype": "enum"
        }
    }
}
```

Setting Custom Field Value on Task
----------------------------------
Use task creation/update endpoints, providing custom field GID and value:

```json
{
  "data": {
    "custom_fields": {
      "ENUM_CUSTOM_FIELD_GID": "SPECIFIC_ENUM_OPTION_GID"
    },
    "name": "Sample Task"
  }
}
```

Important Considerations
-----------------------
- Program defensively
- Custom field metadata can change
- Handle disabled/enabled field states
- Respect access control limitations

9-
10:Asana provides a comprehensive REST API that enables powerful integrations for bug tracking, customer support ticketing, and creative workflow automation. The API uses standard HTTP methods with JSON payloads, supports both Personal Access Tokens (PAT) and OAuth 2.0 authentication, and offers real-time webhook notifications for event-driven workflows.
11-
12-For bug tracking integration, Asana's custom fields system allows you to create structured bug reports with severity levels, priority ratings, and detailed metadata. The Tasks API enables programmatic creation of bug tickets with screenshots, technical details, and automatic assignment to development teams. Rate limits are generous (1,500 requests/minute for paid accounts, 150/minute for free accounts), making it suitable for high-volume integrations.
13-
14-Customer support workflows can leverage Asana's project structure to create dedicated support queues, automatically route tickets based on categories, and sync status updates bidirectionally between your app and Asana. Webhooks enable real-time notifications when support agents update tickets, allowing seamless communication with customers. Popular third-party integrations like SupportBee, HappyFox, and Userback demonstrate proven patterns for support ticket management.
15-
16:The API unlocks numerous creative automation possibilities: AI-powered task naming, automated triage bots, cross-platform content approval workflows, daily summary report generation, and sophisticated multi-tool integrations. Asana's recent AI Studio feature further expands automation capabilities with intelligent task routing and content analysis. Overall, Asana's API is production-ready, well-documented, and actively maintained with official SDKs for Node.js, Python, Java, Ruby, and PHP.

content.text:
Based on the research, here are some **cool things you can do** when integrating Asana with your app:

## ðŸŽ¯ Smart Automation Ideas

### 1. **Automated Sprint Planning**
- Auto-organize bugs/features into sprints based on priority and team capacity
- Calculate "sprint scores" and balance workload across developers
- Send Slack notifications when sprints are planned

### 2. **Customer Feedback Pipeline**
- Collect feedback from NPS surveys, app reviews, support tickets
- Run sentiment analysis (positive/negative/neutral)
- Auto-tag by product area and route to product teams
- Generate weekly feedback theme reports

### 3. **QA Testing Workflow** 
- When devs mark bugs "Ready for Testing", auto-create test tasks
- Copy reproduction steps, add testing checklists
- Round-robin assign to QA team
- Link test tasks to original bugs as dependencies

### 4. **Release Notes Generator**
- At sprint end, auto-generate release notes from completed tasks
- Group by features/improvements/bug fixes
- Post to blog/changelog/newsletter automatically

### 5. **AI-Powered Triage Bot** (using Asana AI Studio)
- AI analyzes task descriptions
- Auto-categorizes and prioritizes based on keywords
- Suggests assignees based on expertise matching
- Posts analysis as comments

### 6. **Content Approval Workflow**
- Monitor Google Drive/Dropbox for new content
- Create approval tasks with file previews
- Route through stakeholders with subtasks
- Auto-publish when all approvals complete

### 7. **SLA Escalation Bot**
- Monitor support ticket age
- Auto-escalate tickets exceeding SLA (4hrs for urgent, 24hrs for high, etc.)
- Reassign to managers, update priority, send alerts

### 8. **Bug Report Screenshots**
- Users submit bugs with screenshots from your app
- Auto-attach images to Asana tasks
- Tag appropriate team members
- Set severity/priority custom fields

### 9. **Daily Team Summaries**
- Generate daily digests of completed work
- Track velocity and trends
- Send to Slack/email
- Celebrate wins and identify blockers

## ðŸ’¡ For Your Social Media Platform Specifically

**You could build:**

- **User-reported bugs** â†’ Asana tasks with platform, severity, reproduction steps
- **Feature requests** â†’ Voting system that creates Asana tasks when threshold reached
- **Content moderation** â†’ Flagged posts become review tasks assigned to moderators
- **User churn alerts** â†’ When users cancel, create task to follow up/investigate
- **Analytics anomalies** â†’ Unusual usage patterns trigger investigation tasks
- **Integration health checks** â†’ Failed social platform syncs create incident tasks

All with bidirectional sync, webhooks for real-time updates, and custom fields tailored to your workflows!

1228:1. **Use OAuth 2.0 for user-facing integrations** - OAuth provides secure, scoped access with user consent and automatic token refresh. 1250:1. **Don't expose Personal Access Tokens in client-side code** - PATs provide full account access and never expire (until manually revoked). Embedding them in frontend JavaScript or mobile apps allows anyone to extract and abuse them. Always use OAuth for client-side apps or proxy requests through your backend.
1251-
1252-2. **Don't poll the API for updates** - Polling is inefficient, wastes rate limit quota, and creates unnecessary load on Asana's servers. Use webhooks for real-time updates instead. For batch operations, poll no more frequently than every 5 minutes and only when webhooks aren't feasible.

1226-### Do's
1227-
1228:1. **Use OAuth 2.0 for user-facing integrations** - OAuth provides secure, scoped access with user consent and automatic token refresh. Personal Access Tokens should only be used for server-to-server integrations and testing. OAuth tokens can be revoked by users and respect workspace permissions, making them safer for production apps.
1229-
1230-2. **Implement webhook signature verification** - Always verify the HMAC signature on incoming webhook requests using the X-Hook-Signature header and your stored webhook secret. This prevents attackers from sending fake events to your endpoint. Use timing-safe comparison (crypto.timingSafeEqual) to avoid timing attacks.
1231-
--
1247-
1248-### Don'ts
1249-
1250:1. **Don't expose Personal Access Tokens in client-side code** - PATs provide full account access and never expire (until manually revoked). Embedding them in frontend JavaScript or mobile apps allows anyone to extract and abuse them. Always use OAuth for client-side apps or proxy requests through your backend.
1251-
1252-2. **Don't poll the API for updates** - Polling is inefficient, wastes rate limit quota, and creates unnecessary load on Asana's servers. Use webhooks for real-time updates instead. For batch operations, poll no more frequently than every 5 minutes and only when webhooks aren't feasible.
